 I completely disagree with the collective right interpretation, but I understand the illogic behind the argument. The collective argument suggests that because the phrase "a well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state" precedes the "right of the people" phrase, then the right intended by the founding fathers must only be a right of the states to arm their militia members free from federal interference. Therefore, collective theorists claim that the "right of the people" really means one of two alternatives: either 1) "right of the states to arm their militias" OR 2) "The right of militia members to bear militia arms when called for service by the state." 
 
 Here, for example, is the Brady Campaign's explanation of the history of the Second Amendment which supports the collective right view: (from http://www.bradycampaign.org/facts/issues/?page=second)
 
 "The History of The Second Amendment: Original Meaning And Intent
 The Second Amendment states: "A well-regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed." The NRA tends to omit the first, crucial, half of the Second Amendment - the words referring to a "well-regulated militia."
 When the U.S. Constitution was adopted, each of the states had its own "militia" - a military force comprised of ordinary citizens serving as part-time soldiers. The militia was "well-regulated" in the sense that its members were subject to various requirements such as training, supplying their own firearms, and engaging in military exercises away from home. It was a form of compulsory military service intended to protect the fledgling nation from outside forces and from internal rebellions.
 The "militia" was not, as the gun lobby will often claim, simply another word for the populace at large. Indeed, membership in the 18th century militia was generally limited to able-bodied white males between the ages of 18 and 45 - hardly encompassing the entire population of the nation.
 The U.S. Constitution established a permanent professional army, controlled by the federal government. With the memory of King George III's troops fresh in their minds, many of the "anti-Federalists" feared a standing army as an instrument of oppression. State militias were viewed as a counterbalance to the federal army and the Second Amendment was written to prevent the federal government from disarming the state militias."
 
 I have a few problems accepting the Collective Right view (beyond wondering why it is that, in covering the over 200 year American history of the RKBA, the Brady Campaign can manage only 4 short paragraphs that contain not a single citation to any source of authority)
 
 The first problem is the placement of the RKBA. When Madison drafted the amendment he and everyone else knew that that there already existed, in Article 1 Section 8, a provision granting the states freedom from federal interference with state control over their militias (namely, the exclusive power granted to the states over appointment of militia officers). If the RKBA were intended to be merely another grant of state power (to be free from federal interference with arming their militias), then Madison should have chosen to place the amendment within Article 1 Section 8, beside the other state power grant. Instead, Madison chose to include the RKBA within a body of other individual liberties.
 
 Secondly, there is the phrase "the right of the people." I think this is what you were driving at, emclean. It is well known that our constitutional form of government is comprised of three separate entities, namely, the federal government, the state governments, and the people. When Madison drafted the Bill of Rights, he clearly understood the principle that the state governments existed as a totally separate entity from the body of "the people." Consider (as you suggest, emclean) the language of the Tenth Amendment, which states:
 
 "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people."
 
 This amendment clearly shows that Madison viewed the "States" as separate from "the People." If, therefore, the Second Amendment was enacted only to protect the right of the States to maintain an armed militia, then why does it read "the right of the people to keep and bear arms" as opposed to "the right of the States to keep and bear arms," or "the right of the States to possess arms for their militias?" (or, for those who favor the alternative collective right view, "the right of militia members to keep and bear their militia arms when called for by the state for militia service?")
 
 But the textual analysis must go further than this, for no one can seriously claim that Madison is guilty of a typographical error. Indeed, the distinct phrase "the right of the people" is used in three different amendments in the Bill of Rights; and Madison clearly intended the phrase to guarantee an individual right each time it is used. For example, the First Amendment states "the right of the people peaceably to assemble. . . ."  The Second Amendment states "the right of the people to keep and bear arms. . . ."  The Fourth Amendments states "the right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures. . . ." As the distinguished Constitutional scholar, Professor Nicholas J. Johnson, noted:
 
 "Indeed, it is hardly credible to assume that the term "the People" was intended to protect the rights of private individuals to assemble peaceably and petition the government in the First Amendment, was somehow transformed in the Second into a right of states, and then miraculously was returned to a right of private individuals to be secure in their persons, houses, papers and effects in the Fourth Amendment." Nicholas J. Johnson, Shots Across No Man's Land: A Response to Handgun Control, Inc.'s, Richard Aborn, 22 Fordham Urb. L.J. 448 (1995).
 
 Third, there is a lengthy history of individual right interpretation in our nation's history, which is too long to post here. Some of that I have already addressed elsewhere on this blog, and can do so again if anyone doubts the overwhelming historical evidence pointing to an individual right intent for the Second Amendment. Let me deal with one case problem in particular, U.S.v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174 (1939), which is often incorrectly cited as supportive of the Collective Right Theory. Here is the problem with that view of Miller: It forgets the first rule you learn in Law School, which is this: No case is ever decided on its merits before SCOTUS unless the party seeking relief has first established standing to raise a claim. That is, you have to prove that the Constitution recognizes your individual right before you can claim it has been violated. If the Miller Court believed the RKBA was only a right of the state to arm it's militia members, then SCOTUS would have dismissed the case per curiam with a short sentence saying "the petitioner, Jack Miller, being an individual citizen and not a state, has no RKBA, and therefore has no standing to allege a violation of a constitutional right." Ah, but what if you use the alternative Collective Right Theory, which suggests that the Second Amendment is a "collective individual right," limited to protecting the right of militia members to bear their militia arms while in service to the state? The answer is the Miller decision would be no different. Jack Miller was a bootlegger, not a member of a state-sponsored militia. If the Miller Court accepted the alternative Collective theory then it would have issued an opinion saying "the petitioner, Jack Miller, not being a member of a state organized militia, has no standing to allege he was denied his right to keep and bear a militia weapon." Instead, SCOTUS assumed that Jack Miller, as an individual citizen not enrolled in a state militia, had an individual RKBA, and therefore had standing to argue whether the particular weapon he was convicted of possessing was protected by the Second Amendment. 
 
 Finally, why then did the state constitutions of the time contain individual right protections for the RKBA? They were drafted long before the Federal Government came into existence, and were intended to protect the individual right from interference by the state....

 "The signification attributed to the term Militia appears from the debates in the Convention, the history and legislation of the Colonies and the States, and the writings of approved commentators. These show plainly enough that the militia comprised all males physically capable of acting in concert for the common defense. "A body of citizens enrolled for military discipline." And further, that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves  and of a kind in common use at the time."
